questions.question: What is the main purpose of containerization in Docker?
questions.correctAnswer: To package applications and their dependencies into a standardized unit for consistent environments
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create virtual machines for running multiple operating systems
questions.wrongAnswer2: To define network policies for container communication
questions.wrongAnswer3: To compile source code into machine code
questions.explanation: Containerization allows applications and their dependencies to be packaged together in a container, ensuring they run consistently across different environments.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a container in Docker?
questions.correctAnswer: A lightweight, standalone, executable package of software including everything needed to run it
questions.wrongAnswer1: A full virtual machine with a separate kernel
questions.wrongAnswer2: A cloud service for hosting applications
questions.wrongAnswer3: A script for automating container deployments
questions.explanation: Docker containers are lightweight and include the application and all its dependencies, but share the host operating system's kernel.

questions.question: How does containerization improve application deployment?
questions.correctAnswer: By ensuring that applications run the same way regardless of the deployment environment
questions.wrongAnswer1: By increasing the size of the software package
questions.wrongAnswer2: By requiring separate kernels for each application
questions.wrongAnswer3: By limiting applications to specific hardware architectures
questions.explanation: Containerization abstracts applications from the underlying environment, which reduces conflicts and increases portability and consistency.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To automate the creation of Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer1: To run Docker containers manually
questions.wrongAnswer2: To write Docker commands interactively
questions.wrongAnswer3: To monitor running Docker containers
questions.explanation: A Dockerfile is a script containing instructions to automate the building of Docker images, specifying the base image and steps to customize it.

questions.question: Which instruction in a Dockerfile specifies the base image to use?
questions.correctAnswer: FROM
questions.wrongAnswer1: RUN
questions.wrongAnswer2: CMD
questions.wrongAnswer3: COPY
questions.explanation: The FROM instruction sets the base image for subsequent instructions in the Dockerfile.

questions.question: In a Dockerfile, what does the RUN instruction do?
questions.correctAnswer: Executes commands in a new layer and commits the results to the image
questions.wrongAnswer1: Copies files from local system to the image
questions.wrongAnswer2: Specifies the default command to run in the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: Sets environment variables for the container
questions.explanation: The RUN instruction runs commands during the image build process, creating new image layers with the resulting changes.

questions.question: What is Docker Compose used for?
questions.correctAnswer: To define and run multi-container Docker applications
questions.wrongAnswer1: To build individual Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage Docker containers on multiple servers
questions.wrongAnswer3: To monitor Docker container performance
questions.explanation: Docker Compose is a tool that allows you to define and run multi-container Docker applications using a YAML file to configure the application services.

questions.question: Which file format does Docker Compose use to configure the services?
questions.correctAnswer: YAML
questions.wrongAnswer1: JSON
questions.wrongAnswer2: XML
questions.wrongAnswer3: INI
questions.explanation: Docker Compose uses a YAML file typically named docker-compose.yml to define the services, networks, and volumes for the application.

questions.question: How do you start the services defined in a Docker Compose file?
questions.correctAnswer: docker-compose up
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker start
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker run
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker-compose start
questions.explanation: The command docker-compose up builds, creates, and starts all the services defined in the Docker Compose file.

questions.question: What is Docker Swarm used for in Docker?
questions.correctAnswer: Orchestrating and managing a cluster of Docker nodes
questions.wrongAnswer1: Building Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer2: Monitoring container logs
questions.wrongAnswer3: Securing Docker containers locally
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm is a native clustering and orchestration tool for Docker that helps manage multiple Docker hosts as a single virtual system.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key feature of Docker Swarm?
questions.correctAnswer: Service discovery and load balancing
questions.wrongAnswer1: Image version control
questions.wrongAnswer2: Continuous integration pipeline
questions.wrongAnswer3: Container debugging tools
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm provides service discovery and can automatically distribute load among containers, making it easier to manage scalable deployments.

questions.question: How does Docker Swarm ensure high availability of services?
questions.correctAnswer: By replicating services across multiple nodes
questions.wrongAnswer1: By storing service logs remotely
questions.wrongAnswer2: By increasing container resource limits
questions.wrongAnswer3: By using a single master node only
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm can maintain multiple replicas of a service running on different nodes, so if one node fails, others continue to serve the requests, ensuring high availability.

questions.question: What is Docker Hub primarily used for?
questions.correctAnswer: A registry service for storing and sharing Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer1: A tool for managing Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: A Docker container orchestration platform
questions.wrongAnswer3: A monitoring tool for Docker environments
questions.explanation: Docker Hub is a cloud-based registry service where users can create, test, store and distribute Docker container images.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a feature of Docker Hub?
questions.correctAnswer: It allows users to find and use container images created by the community
questions.wrongAnswer1: It only supports private image repositories
questions.wrongAnswer2: It is used exclusively for running containers on cloud infrastructure
questions.wrongAnswer3: It replaces Docker Engine for container execution
questions.explanation: Docker Hub provides a public repository where users can access a wide range of pre-built container images shared by the community, as well as private repositories for individual use.

questions.question: How does Docker Hub facilitate collaboration in Docker environments?
questions.correctAnswer: By enabling teams to share and manage Docker images easily through repositories
questions.wrongAnswer1: By providing built-in container orchestration features
questions.wrongAnswer2: By automatically scaling containers deployed from images
questions.wrongAnswer3: By integrating directly with Kubernetes for cluster management
questions.explanation: Docker Hub acts as a centralized platform where teams can collaborate by storing and sharing Docker images, making it easier to manage and deploy consistent container environments.

questions.question: What is a Docker image?
questions.correctAnswer: A lightweight, standalone, and executable software package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software
questions.wrongAnswer1: A running instance of a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer2: A cloud service for deploying containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: A virtual machine used for running Docker
questions.explanation: A Docker image is a lightweight, standalone package which contains the software code along with all dependencies, libraries, tools, and other files needed to run the software. It is used to create Docker containers.

questions.question: Which command is used to create a Docker image from a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: docker build
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker run
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker pull
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker create
questions.explanation: The 'docker build' command reads the Dockerfile in the current directory and assembles a Docker image based on the instructions in the Dockerfile.

questions.question: What differentiates a Docker image from a Docker container?
questions.correctAnswer: An image is a static package used to create containers, while a container is a running instance of an image
questions.wrongAnswer1: An image stores runtime data, while a container is the base template
questions.wrongAnswer2: A container is used to build images
questions.wrongAnswer3: There is no difference, they are interchangeable terms
questions.explanation: Docker images are immutable templates used to create containers. Containers are runtime instances of these images that include the state and processes of the application.

questions.question: What is a Docker container?
questions.correctAnswer: A lightweight, standalone, and executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software
questions.wrongAnswer1: A virtual machine that runs a separate operating system
questions.wrongAnswer2: A physical server where Docker is installed
questions.wrongAnswer3: A tool used to build Docker images
questions.explanation: A Docker container is a lightweight, standalone package that includes everything needed to run a software application, including code, runtime, system tools, libraries, and settings. It is not a virtual machine; it shares the host OS kernel.

questions.question: How do Docker containers differ from virtual machines?
questions.correctAnswer: Containers share the host operating system kernel, while virtual machines run a full guest OS
questions.wrongAnswer1: Containers do not use resources from the host machine
questions.wrongAnswer2: Virtual machines are faster to start than containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: Containers require more disk space than virtual machines
questions.explanation: Docker containers share the host OS kernel making them lightweight and faster to start compared to virtual machines, which require booting an entire guest OS.

questions.question: What command is used to start a Docker container?
questions.correctAnswer: docker run
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker build
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker stop
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker push
questions.explanation: The 'docker run' command is used to start a Docker container from an image, possibly creating a new container if one does not exist.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Docker Volume?
questions.correctAnswer: To persist and share data between containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a new Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage container networking
questions.wrongAnswer3: To monitor container performance
questions.explanation: Docker Volumes are used to persist data generated by and used by Docker containers. This allows data to exist beyond the life of a container and to be shared among multiple containers.

questions.question: Which command is used to create a new Docker Volume?
questions.correctAnswer: docker volume create
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker volume start
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker volume run
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker create volume
questions.explanation: The command docker volume create is used to create a new volume that can be attached to containers for persistent or shared storage.

questions.question: How does a Docker Volume differ from a bind mount?
questions.correctAnswer: Volumes are managed by Docker and are stored in Dockerâ€™s storage area, while bind mounts map directly to files or directories on the host machine.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Volumes are stored on remote servers, bind mounts are local.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Volumes cannot be shared between containers, bind mounts can.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Volumes are read-only, bind mounts are read-write.
questions.explanation: Volumes are managed by Docker, making them easier to back up or migrate and they are stored in a specific Docker location. Bind mounts directly map to a path on the host filesystem, offering more control but less portability.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker network?
questions.correctAnswer: To enable communication between Docker containers and with the outside world
questions.wrongAnswer1: To build Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer2: To execute Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: To store Docker volumes
questions.explanation: Docker network allows containers to communicate with each other and with external networks, which is essential for distributed applications and microservices.

questions.question: Which Docker network driver allows containers to communicate only within the same host?
questions.correctAnswer: Bridge network
questions.wrongAnswer1: Overlay network
questions.wrongAnswer2: Host network
questions.wrongAnswer3: Macvlan network
questions.explanation: The bridge network driver creates a private internal network on the host where containers can communicate with each other but are isolated from external networks unless explicitly connected.

questions.question: What is the function of the Docker overlay network?
questions.correctAnswer: It enables communication between containers running on different Docker hosts
questions.wrongAnswer1: It isolates containers from the host network
questions.wrongAnswer2: It allows containers to share the host's network stack
questions.wrongAnswer3: It is used for storing container data persistently
questions.explanation: Overlay networks span multiple Docker hosts and enable containers to communicate securely as if they were on the same local network, which is useful in swarm mode and multi-host setups.

questions.question: What command is used to list all running Docker containers?
questions.correctAnswer: docker ps
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker ls
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker list
questions.explanation: The command 'docker ps' lists all currently running containers in Docker. Other commands like 'docker ls' or 'docker list' are not valid for listing containers.

questions.question: Which Docker CLI command is used to create and start a container from an image?
questions.correctAnswer: docker run
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker start
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker create
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker init
questions.explanation: The 'docker run' command both creates and starts a container from a specified image. 'docker create' only creates a container without starting it, and 'docker start' is used to start an already created container.

questions.question: How do you stop a running Docker container using the CLI?
questions.correctAnswer: docker stop [container_id]
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker kill [container_id]
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker pause [container_id]
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker remove [container_id]
questions.explanation: The 'docker stop' command stops a running container gracefully. 'docker kill' forces the container to stop immediately, 'docker pause' suspends the container, and 'docker remove' deletes the container.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Docker Registry?
questions.correctAnswer: To store and distribute Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer1: To compile Dockerfiles
questions.wrongAnswer2: To monitor running containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage Docker volumes
questions.explanation: A Docker Registry is used to store and distribute Docker images so that they can be pulled and run on different systems.

questions.question: Which of the following is a popular public Docker Registry?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker Hub
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker Compose
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker Swarm
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker Machine
questions.explanation: Docker Hub is the most widely used public Docker Registry where users can find and share Docker images.

questions.question: What command is used to push a Docker image to a Docker Registry?
questions.correctAnswer: docker push
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker pull
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker run
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker build
questions.explanation: The docker push command uploads your Docker image to a Docker Registry so it can be accessed by others.

questions.question: What is the primary function of Docker Engine?
questions.correctAnswer: To enable containerization by creating and managing containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: To serve as a virtual machine hypervisor
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage Kubernetes clusters
questions.wrongAnswer3: To compile Dockerfiles into executable binaries
questions.explanation: Docker Engine is the core software that enables containerization by creating, running, and managing containers on a host system.

questions.question: Which components are part of the Docker Engine architecture?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker daemon, REST API, Docker CLI
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker Hub, Docker Compose, Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer2: Kubernetes, Docker Swarm, Docker Registry
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker Desktop, Docker Toolbox, Docker Hub
questions.explanation: Docker Engine consists of the Docker daemon that runs containers, the REST API for communication, and the Docker CLI to interact with the daemon.

questions.question: How does Docker Engine differ from a traditional virtual machine hypervisor?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker Engine shares the host OS kernel and runs containers in isolated processes.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker Engine requires a separate OS for each container.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker Engine uses hardware virtualization to run containers.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker Engine creates full guest operating systems for each container.
questions.explanation: Unlike virtual machines that run full guest OS instances, Docker Engine uses containerization that shares the host OS kernel and isolates applications in separate containers, making it lightweight and efficient.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Docker Overlay Network?
questions.correctAnswer: To enable communication between containers running on different Docker hosts
questions.wrongAnswer1: To isolate containers within the same host
questions.wrongAnswer2: To connect Docker containers directly to the internet
questions.wrongAnswer3: To monitor container resource usage
questions.explanation: Docker Overlay Network allows containers running on different Docker hosts to communicate securely as if they were on the same network, facilitating multi-host container clustering.

questions.question: Which technology does Docker Overlay Network use to create a distributed network among Docker hosts?
questions.correctAnswer: VXLAN
questions.wrongAnswer1: IPsec
questions.wrongAnswer2: GRE tunneling
questions.wrongAnswer3: MPLS
questions.explanation: Docker Overlay Network commonly uses VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) to encapsulate container traffic across different Docker hosts, enabling seamless container communication over an underlying network.

questions.question: In which scenario is using a Docker Overlay Network most beneficial?
questions.correctAnswer: When deploying a multi-host Docker Swarm cluster requiring container communication across nodes
questions.wrongAnswer1: Running a single container on a standalone Docker host
questions.wrongAnswer2: Connecting a container to a local bridge network
questions.wrongAnswer3: Improving container startup speed on a single host
questions.explanation: Docker Overlay Network is especially useful in Docker Swarm or Kubernetes environments where services need to communicate across containers on multiple hosts, supporting scalability and service discovery.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Docker Build command?
questions.correctAnswer: To create an image from a Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer1: To run a container from an image
questions.wrongAnswer2: To delete unused Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer3: To push an image to a Docker registry
questions.explanation: The Docker Build command is used to create a Docker image from the instructions specified in a Dockerfile.

questions.question: Which file is essential for the Docker Build command to create an image?
questions.correctAnswer: Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker-compose.yml
questions.wrongAnswer2: README.md
questions.wrongAnswer3: config.json
questions.explanation: The Docker Build command reads instructions from a Dockerfile to build the image.

questions.question: What does the tag option in Docker Build do?
questions.correctAnswer: Assigns a name and optionally a tag to the image
questions.wrongAnswer1: Specifies the base image to use
questions.wrongAnswer2: Sets environment variables in the image
questions.wrongAnswer3: Defines the entry point for the container
questions.explanation: Using the tag option allows you to name your built image and assign a tag for versioning or identification.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker pull command?
questions.correctAnswer: To download an image from a Docker registry to the local machine
questions.wrongAnswer1: To upload a local image to a Docker registry
questions.wrongAnswer2: To remove an image from the local Docker host
questions.wrongAnswer3: To run a container from an image
questions.explanation: The docker pull command is used to fetch/download an image from a Docker registry such as Docker Hub to your local Docker environment, so it can be used to run containers or for other purposes locally.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct usage of the Docker pull command?
questions.correctAnswer: docker pull ubuntu
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker pull run ubuntu
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker pull --start ubuntu
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker pull -rm ubuntu
questions.explanation: The correct usage is docker pull followed by the image name, such as 'ubuntu'. Other options listed are not valid with the pull command.

questions.question: What happens if you use docker pull with an image tag that does not exist?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker returns an error indicating the image could not be found.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker automatically pulls the latest image despite the incorrect tag.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker pulls a default fallback image from the registry.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker ignores the tag and pulls no image.
questions.explanation: If the tag or image name specified does not exist in the registry, Docker will return an error indicating that the image could not be found. It does not default to other images.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the docker push command?
questions.correctAnswer: To upload a local Docker image to a remote registry
questions.wrongAnswer1: To download a Docker image from a remote registry
questions.wrongAnswer2: To create a new Docker image from a Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer3: To remove an image from the local system
questions.explanation: The docker push command is used to upload or push a local Docker image to a remote registry such as Docker Hub, making it available for others to download and use.

questions.question: Before using docker push, what must be done to the image?
questions.correctAnswer: The image must be tagged with the remote registry name
questions.wrongAnswer1: The image must be deleted
questions.wrongAnswer2: The image must be converted to a container
questions.wrongAnswer3: The image must be built using docker pull
questions.explanation: Docker images must be tagged with the repository name and optionally the tag that matches the remote registry before pushing, so docker knows where to send the image.

questions.question: Which of the following is necessary to successfully execute a docker push?
questions.correctAnswer: You must be logged in to the remote Docker registry
questions.wrongAnswer1: You must have running containers based on the image
questions.wrongAnswer2: You must have a Dockerfile present in the current directory
questions.wrongAnswer3: You must have root access on the Docker host machine
questions.explanation: To push images to a private or public remote registry, you need to authenticate with docker login, ensuring you have permissions to upload images.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Docker tag?
questions.correctAnswer: To specify a version or variant of a Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a new Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer2: To run a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To delete an existing Docker image
questions.explanation: A Docker tag is used to specify a particular version or variant of a Docker image, allowing users to manage different image releases.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct format for a Docker tag?
questions.correctAnswer: repository:tag
questions.wrongAnswer1: repository/tag
questions.wrongAnswer2: tag:repository
questions.wrongAnswer3: tag/repository
questions.explanation: The correct format for Docker tags is repository name followed by a colon and then the tag name, for example, ubuntu:20.04.

questions.question: What happens if you do not specify a tag when pulling a Docker image?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker pulls the image with the tag latest by default
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker throws an error and does not pull the image
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker pulls a random tagged image from the repository
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker pulls all images from the repository
questions.explanation: If a tag is not specified, Docker defaults to pulling the image tagged as latest from the repository.

questions.question: What command is used to view the logs of a running Docker container?
questions.correctAnswer: docker logs container_name
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker view container_logs
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker show logs container_name
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker container logs view
questions.explanation: The correct command to view the logs of a running Docker container is docker logs followed by the container name or ID.

questions.question: Which option with docker logs allows you to follow the log output in real-time?
questions.correctAnswer: -f
questions.wrongAnswer1: -a
questions.wrongAnswer2: -t
questions.wrongAnswer3: -n
questions.explanation: The -f option stands for follow and shows the log output in real time as new entries are written to the container's logs.

questions.question: How can you limit the number of log lines shown from a Docker container?
questions.correctAnswer: Using the -n option with docker logs
questions.wrongAnswer1: Using the -l option with docker logs
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using the -c option with docker logs
questions.wrongAnswer3: Using the -r option with docker logs
questions.explanation: The -n option followed by a number limits the output to that many lines from the container's logs.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker Run command?
questions.correctAnswer: To create and start a new container from a specified image
questions.wrongAnswer1: To build a new Docker image from a Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer2: To stop a running container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To list all running containers
questions.explanation: The Docker Run command is used to create and start a new container from a specified Docker image. It sets up the container with the given configuration and begins executing its process.

questions.question: Which of the following options is used with Docker Run to map a container port to a host port?
questions.correctAnswer: -p
questions.wrongAnswer1: -v
questions.wrongAnswer2: -d
questions.wrongAnswer3: --rm
questions.explanation: The -p option in Docker Run maps a port from the container to a port on the host machine, allowing network access through the specified ports.

questions.question: What does the -d flag do when used with the Docker Run command?
questions.correctAnswer: Runs the container in detached mode, in the background
questions.wrongAnswer1: Deletes the container after it stops
questions.wrongAnswer2: Displays detailed logs during container start
questions.wrongAnswer3: Limits the container's CPU usage
questions.explanation: The -d flag tells Docker to run the container in detached mode, which means the container runs in the background and does not block the terminal.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker exec command?
questions.correctAnswer: To run a new command in a running container
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a new container
questions.wrongAnswer2: To build a Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer3: To stop a running container
questions.explanation: The Docker exec command is used to run a new command or process inside an already running container without starting a new container from scratch.

questions.question: Which of the following commands correctly demonstrates how to use Docker exec to start an interactive bash shell inside a running container named mycontainer?
questions.correctAnswer: docker exec -it mycontainer bash
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker exec mycontainer -it bash
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker container run -it mycontainer bash
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker start -it mycontainer bash
questions.explanation: The correct syntax for running an interactive bash shell inside a container is docker exec with the -it flags followed by the container name and the command bash.

questions.question: What do the -i and -t options signify in the command docker exec -it container_name bash?
questions.correctAnswer: -i keeps STDIN open, -t allocates a pseudo-TTY
questions.wrongAnswer1: -i stops the container, -t removes the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: -i builds the image, -t tags the image
questions.wrongAnswer3: -i lists containers, -t restarts the container
questions.explanation: The -i option keeps the container's standard input open, and -t allocates a pseudo-terminal, allowing interactive processes like bash to run properly.

questions.question: What does the docker stop command do?
questions.correctAnswer: It stops a running container gracefully by sending a SIGTERM signal.
questions.wrongAnswer1: It removes a stopped container from the system.
questions.wrongAnswer2: It forcefully kills a container immediately without cleanup.
questions.wrongAnswer3: It pauses the container process temporarily.
questions.explanation: The docker stop command sends a SIGTERM to the main process inside the container, allowing it to terminate gracefully before the container is stopped entirely.

questions.question: How does docker stop differ from docker kill?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker stop sends SIGTERM allowing graceful shutdown, docker kill sends SIGKILL immediately stopping the container.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker stop removes the container, docker kill only pauses it.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker stop is for creating containers, docker kill is for deleting images.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker stop runs the container, docker kill rebuilds it.
questions.explanation: docker stop tries to shut down the container's main process cleanly by sending SIGTERM, while docker kill sends SIGKILL to terminate the process immediately without cleanup.

questions.question: What happens if a container does not stop after docker stop is issued?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker waits for a timeout period then sends SIGKILL to force stop the container.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker immediately deletes the container without stopping it.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker restarts the container automatically after the stop attempt.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker converts the running container to a paused state.
questions.explanation: If the container does not stop within the default timeout after receiving SIGTERM, docker stop sends SIGKILL to force termination of the container process.

questions.question: What does the Docker Start command do?
questions.correctAnswer: It starts a stopped container
questions.wrongAnswer1: It builds a new container image
questions.wrongAnswer2: It stops a running container
questions.wrongAnswer3: It removes an existing container
questions.explanation: The Docker Start command is used to start a container that has been stopped. It does not build or remove containers, nor does it stop them.

questions.question: Which of these commands would you use to start an existing container named my_container?
questions.correctAnswer: docker start my_container
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker run my_container
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker build my_container
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker stop my_container
questions.explanation: The correct command to start an existing stopped container named my_container is docker start my_container. docker run is for running a new container, docker build builds images, and docker stop stops running containers.

questions.question: If a container is already running, what happens when you run docker start on it?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker returns an error saying the container is already running
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker restarts the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker stops the container then starts it again
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker does nothing silently
questions.explanation: Attempting to start a container that is already running will result in Docker returning an error indicating the container is already running. It does not silently do nothing or restart the container automatically.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker Inspect command?
questions.correctAnswer: To display detailed information about Docker objects such as containers and images
questions.wrongAnswer1: To remove Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: To start a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To download Docker images
questions.explanation: Docker Inspect is used to retrieve detailed low-level information about Docker objects including containers, images, networks, and volumes, providing metadata in JSON format.

questions.question: Which format does Docker Inspect use to present the details of the inspected object?
questions.correctAnswer: JSON
questions.wrongAnswer1: XML
questions.wrongAnswer2: YAML
questions.wrongAnswer3: Plain text
questions.explanation: Docker Inspect returns information in JSON format, which includes configuration details and state information of Docker objects.

questions.question: You ran Docker Inspect on a container and want to find out its IP address. Where in the JSON output would you most likely find this information?
questions.correctAnswer: Under NetworkSettings
questions.wrongAnswer1: Under Config
questions.wrongAnswer2: Under Mounts
questions.wrongAnswer3: Under State
questions.explanation: Network-related information such as IP addresses can be found under the NetworkSettings section in the Docker Inspect JSON output.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker API?
questions.correctAnswer: To allow programmatic interaction with the Docker daemon
questions.wrongAnswer1: To provide a graphical interface for managing Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: To replace the Docker CLI for manual container management
questions.wrongAnswer3: To monitor server hardware performance
questions.explanation: The Docker API is designed to allow programs to interact with the Docker daemon, enabling automation and integration with other software.

questions.question: Which protocol does the Docker API primarily use to communicate?
questions.correctAnswer: HTTP over a RESTful interface
questions.wrongAnswer1: FTP for file transfers
questions.wrongAnswer2: SSH for secure command execution
questions.wrongAnswer3: SMTP for message sending
questions.explanation: Docker API uses a RESTful HTTP interface allowing clients to control Docker daemon remotely.

questions.question: How can the Docker API be accessed securely?
questions.correctAnswer: By using TLS encryption and client certificates
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using only username and password authentication
questions.wrongAnswer2: By disabling authentication for easier access
questions.wrongAnswer3: By using FTP over SSH tunneling
questions.explanation: Securing the Docker API involves using TLS certificates to encrypt communication and authenticate clients to the Docker daemon.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Secrets?
questions.correctAnswer: To securely store and manage sensitive data such as passwords and keys
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage container networking configurations
questions.wrongAnswer2: To monitor container resource usage
questions.wrongAnswer3: To automate container deployment
questions.explanation: Docker Secrets are designed to securely store sensitive information like passwords, tokens, or keys and provide controlled access to containers without exposing the data in the image or environment variables.

questions.question: Which Docker feature must be enabled to use Docker Secrets?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker Swarm mode
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker Compose
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker Hub
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker Volumes
questions.explanation: Docker Secrets are a feature that requires Docker Swarm mode, which is used to orchestrate multiple containers and securely manage secrets for services.

questions.question: How are Docker Secrets typically accessed inside a container?
questions.correctAnswer: As files mounted in a secure in-memory filesystem
questions.wrongAnswer1: As environment variables visible to all containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: Through network API calls
questions.wrongAnswer3: By exposing secrets in container logs
questions.explanation: Docker injects secrets into containers as files mounted in a tmpfs (in-memory) filesystem, ensuring the secret data is not stored on disk and is only available for the container that requires it.

questions.question: What is Docker Stack primarily used for?
questions.correctAnswer: Deploying and managing a group of related services in Docker Swarm
questions.wrongAnswer1: Building individual Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer2: Monitoring container resource usage
questions.wrongAnswer3: Running containers on a single host without orchestration
questions.explanation: Docker Stack is used to deploy and manage multi-service applications on a Docker Swarm cluster using a stack file that defines the services.

questions.question: Which file format is typically used to define a Docker Stack?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker Compose YAML file
questions.wrongAnswer1: JSON file
questions.wrongAnswer2: Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer3: XML file
questions.explanation: Docker Stack uses Docker Compose YAML files to define the services, networks, and volumes that make up the stack.

questions.question: Which command is used to deploy a Docker Stack to a swarm?
questions.correctAnswer: docker stack deploy
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker stack launch
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker-compose up
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker run
questions.explanation: The docker stack deploy command is used to deploy a stack to the Docker Swarm cluster based on the specified Compose file.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Docker Service?
questions.correctAnswer: To manage and maintain a set of containers as a single scalable application
questions.wrongAnswer1: To install Docker on multiple machines automatically
questions.wrongAnswer2: To provide a graphical interface for Docker container management
questions.wrongAnswer3: To build Docker images from a Dockerfile
questions.explanation: A Docker Service is used to deploy and manage a group of containers as a single scalable application, allowing for load balancing and easy updates.

questions.question: Which Docker component is responsible for orchestrating Docker Services?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker Swarm
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker Compose
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker Hub
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker Machine
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm is the native clustering and orchestration tool for Docker Services, managing service deployment, scaling, and maintenance.

questions.question: In Docker Service, what does a task represent?
questions.correctAnswer: An instance of a container running as part of a service
questions.wrongAnswer1: A single command to build a Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer2: A user request to upload images to Docker Hub
questions.wrongAnswer3: A configuration file for service networking
questions.explanation: A task in Docker Service represents a container instance running on a node as part of the service's desired state.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker HEALTHCHECK instruction?
questions.correctAnswer: To specify a command that tests if the container is healthy
questions.wrongAnswer1: To set the maximum memory usage of a container
questions.wrongAnswer2: To configure network settings for the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To define the container restart policy
questions.explanation: The HEALTHCHECK instruction in a Dockerfile defines a command that Docker uses to determine if the container is still working correctly or healthy.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about Docker HEALTHCHECK intervals?
questions.correctAnswer: You can configure how often the healthcheck command runs
questions.wrongAnswer1: Healthcheck commands only run once when the container starts
questions.wrongAnswer2: Healthchecks run only manually when triggered by the user
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker automatically runs healthchecks every second without configuration
questions.explanation: The HEALTHCHECK instruction allows configuration of parameters like interval, timeout, and retries to control how often and under what conditions the healthcheck command runs.

questions.question: How does Docker indicate a container is unhealthy based on healthcheck status?
questions.correctAnswer: Container status changes to unhealthy if the healthcheck command fails repeatedly
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker immediately stops the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: Container is restarted automatically once a healthcheck fails once
questions.wrongAnswer3: The container becomes read-only when unhealthy
questions.explanation: If the healthcheck command fails repeatedly as configured, Docker marks the container as unhealthy but does not automatically stop or restart it unless configured via orchestration tools.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the COPY instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To copy files or directories from the host system into the Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer1: To copy files from one Docker image to another
questions.wrongAnswer2: To copy files from a running container back to the host
questions.wrongAnswer3: To copy commands from one Dockerfile to another
questions.explanation: The COPY instruction in a Dockerfile is used to copy files or directories from the build context (host system) into the Docker image during the image build process.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct syntax for the COPY instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: COPY source destination
questions.wrongAnswer1: COPY destination source
questions.wrongAnswer2: COPY -source destination
questions.wrongAnswer3: COPY @source -> destination
questions.explanation: The proper syntax for the COPY instruction is COPY followed by the source path and the destination path inside the image.

questions.question: What will happen if you use COPY to copy a directory but the destination directory does not exist in the Docker image?
questions.correctAnswer: Docker will create the destination directory and copy the contents
questions.wrongAnswer1: The build will fail with an error
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker will copy the contents to the root directory instead
questions.wrongAnswer3: The copied files will be ignored
questions.explanation: COPY will create the destination directory if it doesn't exist and then copy all files and subdirectories from the source directory.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the RUN instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To execute commands and install software during the image build process
questions.wrongAnswer1: To specify the base image for the Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer2: To define environment variables used in the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To expose network ports for container communication
questions.explanation: The RUN instruction allows you to execute commands, such as installing packages or setting up the environment, while building the Docker image.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid use of the RUN instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y nginx
questions.wrongAnswer1: RUN EXPOSE 80
questions.wrongAnswer2: RUN FROM ubuntu
questions.wrongAnswer3: RUN CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]
questions.explanation: RUN is used to run commands like package installation; EXPOSE, FROM, and CMD are separate Dockerfile instructions and cannot be used with RUN.

questions.question: How does using multiple RUN instructions in a Dockerfile affect the image?
questions.correctAnswer: Each RUN creates a new layer, potentially increasing image size
questions.wrongAnswer1: All RUN commands are combined into a single layer automatically
questions.wrongAnswer2: RUN instructions only execute when the container starts
questions.wrongAnswer3: RUN commands are ignored and do not affect the image layers
questions.explanation: Each RUN instruction creates a new image layer; combining commands in a single RUN reduces the total number of layers and can make the image smaller.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the CMD instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: It specifies the default command to run when a container starts
questions.wrongAnswer1: It copies files from the host to the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: It sets environment variables inside the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: It defines network settings for the container
questions.explanation: The CMD instruction in a Dockerfile provides the default command that executes when a container is run from the image. It can be overridden at runtime.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid usage of the CMD instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]
questions.wrongAnswer1: CMD RUN apt-get update
questions.wrongAnswer2: CMD ENV PATH /usr/local/bin
questions.wrongAnswer3: CMD COPY . /app
questions.explanation: CMD supports exec form (as a JSON array) or shell form (a simple string). The example uses the exec form which is preferred for clarity and signal handling.

questions.question: If a Dockerfile contains multiple CMD instructions, which one takes effect?
questions.correctAnswer: Only the last CMD instruction is used
questions.wrongAnswer1: The first CMD instruction is used
questions.wrongAnswer2: All CMD instructions are combined and executed
questions.wrongAnswer3: None of the CMD instructions are used
questions.explanation: Dockerfile processes only the last CMD instruction. All previous CMDs are ignored as they get overwritten by the next CMD.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the ENTRYPOINT instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To define the executable that will run when a container starts from the image
questions.wrongAnswer1: To copy files into the Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer2: To set environment variables for the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To expose network ports from the container
questions.explanation: The ENTRYPOINT instruction specifies the command that will always be executed when the container starts. It sets the container's main process.

questions.question: How does ENTRYPOINT differ from the CMD instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: ENTRYPOINT defines the executable, CMD provides default arguments to it
questions.wrongAnswer1: CMD sets the executable, ENTRYPOINT provides default arguments
questions.wrongAnswer2: Both do the same thing and are interchangeable
questions.wrongAnswer3: ENTRYPOINT is used for environment variables and CMD for startup commands
questions.explanation: ENTRYPOINT specifies the command to execute, while CMD specifies default arguments that can be overridden at runtime.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct way to write an ENTRYPOINT instruction in exec form in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: ENTRYPOINT ["/usr/bin/myapp", "--flag"]
questions.wrongAnswer1: ENTRYPOINT /usr/bin/myapp --flag
questions.wrongAnswer2: ENTRYPOINT /usr/bin/myapp, --flag
questions.wrongAnswer3: ENTRYPOINT "/usr/bin/myapp --flag"
questions.explanation: The exec form uses JSON array syntax, specifying the executable and arguments as elements. This prevents shell interpretation.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the ENV instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To set environment variables in the container
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a network bridge for container communication
questions.wrongAnswer2: To specify the base image for the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To launch the container in detached mode
questions.explanation: The ENV instruction in a Dockerfile is used to set environment variables that will be available to the applications running inside the container.

questions.question: Where are environment variables set by the ENV instruction available?
questions.correctAnswer: Inside the container at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer1: Only during the image build process
questions.wrongAnswer2: Only on the host system
questions.wrongAnswer3: In the Docker daemon configuration
questions.explanation: Environment variables set using ENV are available inside the container whenever it runs, making it possible to configure the containerized application.

questions.question: Which syntax correctly sets an environment variable named APP_ENV to production in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: ENV APP_ENV production
questions.wrongAnswer1: ENV APP_ENV=production
questions.wrongAnswer2: SET APP_ENV=production
questions.wrongAnswer3: RUN ENV APP_ENV production
questions.explanation: The correct syntax for the ENV instruction is 'ENV key value' without equals sign. Therefore, 'ENV APP_ENV production' is the correct way to set the environment variable APP_ENV to production inside a Dockerfile.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To document which ports the container listens on at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer1: To publish the container's ports to the host machine automatically
questions.wrongAnswer2: To open firewall ports on the Docker host
questions.wrongAnswer3: To assign a fixed IP address to the container
questions.explanation: The EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile is used to indicate which ports the container will listen on during runtime. It serves as documentation and does not automatically publish or map the ports.

questions.question: Does the EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile make the port accessible from the host machine by default?
questions.correctAnswer: No, EXPOSE only serves as documentation and does not publish the port
questions.wrongAnswer1: Yes, it automatically opens the port to the host
questions.wrongAnswer2: Yes, it configures the firewall to allow traffic through
questions.wrongAnswer3: No, EXPOSE disables port access from outside the container
questions.explanation: EXPOSE in a Dockerfile does not publish ports or make them accessible from the host machine by default. To access container ports, you need to explicitly map them using the -p option when running the container.

questions.question: How can you make a port exposed by EXPOSE accessible on the host machine?
questions.correctAnswer: By using the -p or --publish option when running the container
questions.wrongAnswer1: By adding another EXPOSE instruction with the same port
questions.wrongAnswer2: By restarting the Docker daemon
questions.wrongAnswer3: By adding the port number to the container's environment variables
questions.explanation: The EXPOSE instruction only documents ports within the Dockerfile. To make them accessible from the host, you must use the -p or --publish option in the docker run command to map container ports to host ports.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the VOLUME instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To create a mount point with a specified path and mark it as a volume for persistent data storage
questions.wrongAnswer1: To install software packages inside the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: To set environment variables inside the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: To specify the working directory for any RUN, CMD, ENTRYPOINT commands
questions.explanation: The VOLUME instruction in a Dockerfile defines a mount point and marks it as a volume, which allows data to persist outside the container's writable layer, enabling data sharing and persistence.

questions.question: Which command in a Dockerfile would you use to declare a directory as a volume?
questions.correctAnswer: VOLUME ["/data"]
questions.wrongAnswer1: VOLUME /data
questions.wrongAnswer2: EXPOSE /data
questions.wrongAnswer3: RUN VOLUME /data
questions.explanation: The VOLUME instruction can take JSON array format to specify one or more directories as volumes. For example, VOLUME ["/data"] declares /data as a volume.

questions.question: What happens to the data stored in a Docker volume when the container is deleted?
questions.correctAnswer: The data persists outside of the container and is not deleted automatically
questions.wrongAnswer1: The data is deleted immediately
questions.wrongAnswer2: The data is moved to the container's image
questions.wrongAnswer3: The data is encrypted and saved in the container logs
questions.explanation: Volumes are designed to persist data independently from container lifecycle, so deleting the container does not remove the data stored in volumes unless explicitly deleted.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the WORKDIR instruction in a Dockerfile
questions.correctAnswer: It sets the working directory for instructions that follow in the Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer1: It defines the base image for the Docker build process
questions.wrongAnswer2: It installs necessary packages inside the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: It specifies the network configuration for the container
questions.explanation: The WORKDIR instruction in a Dockerfile sets the working directory for any RUN, CMD, ENTRYPOINT, COPY, and ADD instructions that follow it. If the directory does not exist, it will be created.

questions.question: If a Dockerfile contains multiple WORKDIR instructions, what happens
questions.correctAnswer: Each WORKDIR overrides the previous one and sets a new working directory
questions.wrongAnswer1: The first WORKDIR instruction is the only one that takes effect
questions.wrongAnswer2: All WORKDIR instructions are concatenated to form the final directory path
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker build fails with an error because multiple WORKDIRs are not allowed
questions.explanation: Multiple WORKDIR instructions in a Dockerfile are allowed, and each one sets the working directory relative to the previous one, effectively overriding the current directory for subsequent instructions.

questions.question: How does the WORKDIR instruction handle relative paths in a Dockerfile
questions.correctAnswer: It treats the relative path as relative to the current WORKDIR or root if none is set
questions.wrongAnswer1: It treats the relative path as relative to the root of the host machine
questions.wrongAnswer2: It ignores relative paths and only accepts absolute paths
questions.wrongAnswer3: It treats the relative path as the path inside the source directory on the build machine
questions.explanation: When the WORKDIR instruction uses a relative path, it is interpreted relative to the path set by the previous WORKDIR instruction. If no WORKDIR has been set, it is relative to the root directory in the container.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the ARG instruction in a Dockerfile?
questions.correctAnswer: To define a variable that users can pass at build-time to the Docker image
questions.wrongAnswer1: To define environment variables available in the container at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer2: To specify the base image of the Dockerfile
questions.wrongAnswer3: To add files to the Docker image
questions.explanation: The ARG instruction lets you define variables that can be passed during the image build process. These variables are not available after the image is built as environment variables are. ARG is used to customize builds.

questions.question: When can the value of an ARG variable be overridden?
questions.correctAnswer: Only at build-time using the --build-arg flag with docker build
questions.wrongAnswer1: At runtime when starting a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer2: By editing the Dockerfile after the image is built
questions.wrongAnswer3: By configuring the Docker daemon settings
questions.explanation: ARG variables can be overridden only during the image build process by passing --build-arg arguments to docker build. They cannot be changed at runtime or after the image is created.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ARG in Dockerfiles is true?
questions.correctAnswer: ARG variables are not persisted in the final image as environment variables
questions.wrongAnswer1: ARG variables are available inside the container at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer2: ARG is used to run commands inside the container
questions.wrongAnswer3: ARG variables must be declared after the CMD instruction
questions.explanation: ARG variables are used for build-time parameters only and do not persist as environment variables in the final image. They are not accessible during container runtime, unlike ENV variables.

questions.question: What is a Docker Bind Mount used for?
questions.correctAnswer: To mount a directory or file from the host machine into a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a new Docker image from a container
questions.wrongAnswer2: To isolate containers from the host file system
questions.wrongAnswer3: To automatically update the Docker container when the image changes
questions.explanation: A Docker Bind Mount allows you to mount a directory or file from the host machine into a container at runtime, enabling the container to access and modify files on the host.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes how to specify a bind mount in a docker run command?
questions.correctAnswer: Using the -v or --volume flag followed by host_path:container_path
questions.wrongAnswer1: Using the --bind flag followed by container_path:host_path
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using the -m flag followed by container_path:host_path
questions.wrongAnswer3: Using the --mount flag with image name and version
questions.explanation: The -v or --volume flag in docker run command is used to create a bind mount by specifying the path on the host and the path inside the container separated by a colon.

questions.question: What is a key difference between Docker bind mounts and Docker volumes?
questions.correctAnswer: Bind mounts directly link host files or directories to containers, volumes are managed by Docker and stored in a Docker-specific location
questions.wrongAnswer1: Bind mounts cannot be used with Docker Compose, volumes can
questions.wrongAnswer2: Volumes mount files from the host directory, bind mounts mount files from a Docker volume
questions.wrongAnswer3: Bind mounts provide network isolation, volumes do not
questions.explanation: Bind mounts use the actual file or directory from the host machine, giving direct access to host filesystem paths. Volumes are stored in a Docker-managed location and offer better portability and management features.

questions.question: What does the docker stats command display?
questions.correctAnswer: Real-time resource usage statistics for running containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: A list of all Docker images on the system
questions.wrongAnswer2: The history of a specific Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer3: The Docker daemon logs
questions.explanation: The docker stats command provides live data on CPU, memory, network, and disk usage for active containers, allowing monitoring of resource consumption.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically displayed by the docker stats command?
questions.correctAnswer: Container build time
questions.wrongAnswer1: CPU usage
questions.wrongAnswer2: Memory usage
questions.wrongAnswer3: Network I/O
questions.explanation: Docker stats shows metrics related to container performance such as CPU usage, memory usage, and network I/O, but does not show metadata like container build time.

questions.question: How can you use docker stats to monitor specific containers?
questions.correctAnswer: By providing one or more container IDs or names as arguments
questions.wrongAnswer1: By filtering metrics in the Docker dashboard
questions.wrongAnswer2: By setting a configuration file with container names
questions.wrongAnswer3: By using the docker inspect command in conjunction
questions.explanation: To monitor specific containers with docker stats, you can specify their IDs or names after the command to limit the output to those containers only.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Docker prune command?
questions.correctAnswer: To remove unused Docker objects such as containers, networks, images, and volumes
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create new Docker containers quickly
questions.wrongAnswer2: To optimize Docker container performance
questions.wrongAnswer3: To build Docker images from a Dockerfile
questions.explanation: The Docker prune command is used to clean up your Docker environment by removing unused and dangling objects, freeing up disk space.

questions.question: Which Docker command would you use to remove all stopped containers, unused networks, dangling images, and build cache at once?
questions.correctAnswer: docker system prune
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker container prune
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker image prune
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker network prune
questions.explanation: The command docker system prune removes all unused data including stopped containers, unused networks, dangling images, and build caches in a single operation.

questions.question: If you want to remove only unused Docker images that are not referenced by any container, which command would be most appropriate?
questions.correctAnswer: docker image prune
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker system prune
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker container prune
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker volume prune
questions.explanation: The docker image prune command specifically targets unused Docker images, removing only those images that are not associated with any container.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Context?
questions.correctAnswer: To manage different Docker environments and endpoints
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create Docker images from Dockerfiles
questions.wrongAnswer2: To monitor the resource usage of Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: To optimize Docker container networking performance
questions.explanation: Docker Context allows users to switch between multiple Docker endpoints or environments, such as local or remote Docker hosts, making management easier.

questions.question: Which command is used to create a new Docker Context?
questions.correctAnswer: docker context create
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker context new
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker create context
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker context add
questions.explanation: The command docker context create is used to create a new Docker Context with specified settings.

questions.question: How can you list all available Docker Contexts on your machine?
questions.correctAnswer: docker context ls
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker context list all
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker contexts show
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker ls contexts
questions.explanation: The command docker context ls lists all the Docker Contexts available on your system, showing their names and endpoints.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Secrets Management?
questions.correctAnswer: To securely store and manage sensitive data such as passwords and API keys
questions.wrongAnswer1: To speed up Docker container builds
questions.wrongAnswer2: To monitor container performance
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage Docker network settings
questions.explanation: Docker Secrets Management is designed to securely store and manage sensitive information like passwords, API keys, and certificates, preventing exposure in Docker containers.

questions.question: How are Docker secrets typically accessed by containers?
questions.correctAnswer: They are mounted as files inside the container at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer1: They are embedded in the container environment variables
questions.wrongAnswer2: They are stored in a public Docker registry
questions.wrongAnswer3: They are downloaded from the internet by the container
questions.explanation: Docker secrets are mounted as files inside the container at runtime, providing secure access without exposing the secrets in environment variables or image layers.

questions.question: Which Docker command is used to create a secret?
questions.correctAnswer: docker secret create
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker secret init
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker service create
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker volume create
questions.explanation: The command docker secret create is used to create a new secret in Docker that can then be used by Docker services.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a Docker Compose override file?
questions.correctAnswer: To override or add configurations to the base Docker Compose file
questions.wrongAnswer1: To replace Dockerfiles entirely
questions.wrongAnswer2: To configure the Docker daemon settings
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage container runtime logs
questions.explanation: A Docker Compose override file is used to override or add to the settings defined in the base Docker Compose file, allowing customization without modifying the original file directly.

questions.question: When using Docker Compose, which file is automatically used alongside docker-compose.yml?
questions.correctAnswer: docker-compose.override.yml
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker-compose.prod.yml
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker-compose.config.yml
questions.wrongAnswer3: dockerfile.override.yml
questions.explanation: Docker Compose automatically uses docker-compose.override.yml as an override file to extend or modify the base configuration in docker-compose.yml.

questions.question: How can you apply multiple Docker Compose override files when starting your services?
questions.correctAnswer: By using the -f flag multiple times in the docker-compose command
questions.wrongAnswer1: By placing all overrides inside a single docker-compose.override.yml file
questions.wrongAnswer2: By renaming files and running docker-compose again
questions.wrongAnswer3: By setting environment variables in the docker-compose.yml
questions.explanation: You can specify multiple override files using the -f option multiple times in your docker-compose command to combine or override different configurations.

questions.question: What does Docker in Docker (DinD) mean?
questions.correctAnswer: Running Docker inside a Docker container
questions.wrongAnswer1: Using Docker to run only one container
questions.wrongAnswer2: Running multiple Docker containers without Docker
questions.wrongAnswer3: Running Docker without a container
questions.explanation: Docker in Docker refers to running Docker inside a Docker container, allowing for nested containerization.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common use case for Docker in Docker?
questions.correctAnswer: CI/CD pipelines to build Docker images inside containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: Running Docker containers on bare metal servers without any virtualization
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using Docker containers only for persistent storage
questions.wrongAnswer3: Replacing virtual machines with Docker containers
questions.explanation: Docker in Docker is often used in CI/CD environments where Docker containers themselves need to run Docker commands to build and manage other containers.

questions.question: What is a major challenge when using Docker in Docker?
questions.correctAnswer: Managing Docker daemon access and security inside containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: Docker containers cannot be started inside other containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: Docker images cannot be shared between containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker containers run slower on Linux hosts
questions.explanation: A common challenge with Docker in Docker is securely managing access to the Docker daemon and avoiding permission or isolation issues.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Machine?
questions.correctAnswer: To provision and manage Docker hosts on local and remote platforms
questions.wrongAnswer1: To build Docker images
questions.wrongAnswer2: To monitor Docker container performance
questions.wrongAnswer3: To deploy Docker containers on Kubernetes
questions.explanation: Docker Machine is used to provision and manage Docker hosts on various platforms, including local machines and cloud providers, enabling easier Docker environment setup.

questions.question: Which of the following commands is used to create a Docker host with Docker Machine?
questions.correctAnswer: docker-machine create
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker-machine start
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker-machine build
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker-machine run
questions.explanation: The docker-machine create command is used to create a new Docker host on a specified platform.

questions.question: Which cloud providers are commonly supported by Docker Machine for provisioning hosts?
questions.correctAnswer: Amazon EC2, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform
questions.wrongAnswer1: Salesforce, SAP, Oracle Cloud
questions.wrongAnswer2: DigitalOcean, GitHub, Heroku
questions.wrongAnswer3: IBM Watson, Dropbox, Slack
questions.explanation: Docker Machine supports provisioning hosts on popular cloud providers like Amazon EC2, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform among others.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Trusted Registry?
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a secure and private Docker image storage solution
questions.wrongAnswer1: To replace Docker Engine on the host system
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage network configurations for Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer3: To automate container orchestration like Kubernetes
questions.explanation: Docker Trusted Registry is designed to offer secure, private storage for Docker container images, enabling enterprises to manage and control image distribution within their environments.

questions.question: Which of the following features is a key benefit of using Docker Trusted Registry?
questions.correctAnswer: Role-based access control for image repositories
questions.wrongAnswer1: Automatic container scaling based on resource usage
questions.wrongAnswer2: Built-in container runtime environment
questions.wrongAnswer3: Direct integration with Docker Compose files
questions.explanation: Docker Trusted Registry provides role-based access control which allows administrators to control who can view, push, or pull images from repositories, enhancing security.

questions.question: How does Docker Trusted Registry enhance security compared to public Docker registries?
questions.correctAnswer: By allowing organizations to host images internally with access controls
questions.wrongAnswer1: By providing free image hosting to all users
questions.wrongAnswer2: By automatically scanning containers for vulnerabilities at runtime
questions.wrongAnswer3: By replacing the need for container image signing
questions.explanation: With Docker Trusted Registry, organizations can keep container images on-premise or in private clouds, enforce access policies, and control distribution to ensure security compliance unlike public registries.

questions.question: What is Docker Cloud primarily used for?
questions.correctAnswer: Managing and deploying Docker containers in a cloud environment
questions.wrongAnswer1: Creating virtual machines
questions.wrongAnswer2: Writing Dockerfile scripts
questions.wrongAnswer3: Managing databases
questions.explanation: Docker Cloud is a service that allows users to deploy, manage, and scale Dockerized applications in cloud environments, integrating container orchestration and deployment workflows.

questions.question: Which feature is a key benefit of using Docker Cloud?
questions.correctAnswer: Automated deployment and scaling of containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: Manual server provisioning
questions.wrongAnswer2: Static website hosting
questions.wrongAnswer3: Local container debugging
questions.explanation: Docker Cloud provides automation for deploying and scaling containerized applications, allowing easier management of clusters and services in the cloud.

questions.question: How does Docker Cloud integrate with version control systems?
questions.correctAnswer: It connects to repositories to trigger automated builds and deployments
questions.wrongAnswer1: It replaces version control systems
questions.wrongAnswer2: It stores code backups
questions.wrongAnswer3: It provides code review tools
questions.explanation: Docker Cloud can link to GitHub, Bitbucket, or other repositories to automate building, testing, and deploying container images based on source code changes.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Docker Desktop?
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a user-friendly environment for building and sharing containerized applications on a desktop
questions.wrongAnswer1: To serve as a server for running multiple virtual machines
questions.wrongAnswer2: To replace the operating system on a computer
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage cloud resources directly
questions.explanation: Docker Desktop is designed to offer an easy-to-use interface and environment for developers to build, run, and share containerized applications directly on their desktop computers.

questions.question: Which operating systems support Docker Desktop?
questions.correctAnswer: Windows and macOS
questions.wrongAnswer1: Only Linux
questions.wrongAnswer2: Windows and Linux only
questions.wrongAnswer3: All operating systems including mobile
questions.explanation: Docker Desktop is officially supported on Windows and macOS platforms to provide a seamless Docker experience on desktop computers.

questions.question: Which of these features is included in Docker Desktop?
questions.correctAnswer: Kubernetes integration for container orchestration
questions.wrongAnswer1: Built-in code editor for software development
questions.wrongAnswer2: Database management system
questions.wrongAnswer3: Cloud hosting service
questions.explanation: Docker Desktop includes Kubernetes integration, allowing developers to run and manage Kubernetes clusters locally for container orchestration.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Docker Data Volume Container?
questions.correctAnswer: To persist and share data between multiple Docker containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: To isolate the network configuration of containers
questions.wrongAnswer2: To build Docker images from Dockerfiles
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage container orchestration and scaling
questions.explanation: A Docker Data Volume Container is used to persist data independent of the container's lifecycle and to share this data with other containers.

questions.question: How does a Docker Data Volume Container help when containers are removed or recreated?
questions.correctAnswer: It keeps the data intact and available for new containers
questions.wrongAnswer1: It deletes all associated data along with the container
questions.wrongAnswer2: It automatically backs up data to the host machine
questions.wrongAnswer3: It merges data from all active containers
questions.explanation: Data stored in volume containers is preserved even if the container itself is deleted, making data persistent beyond container life.

questions.question: Which Docker command is used to create a Data Volume Container?
questions.correctAnswer: docker create -v /data --name datavolume busybox
questions.wrongAnswer1: docker run --network datavolume busybox
questions.wrongAnswer2: docker volume create datavolume
questions.wrongAnswer3: docker build -t datavolume .
questions.explanation: To create a Docker Data Volume Container, you typically use docker create with the -v option to specify the volume and assign the container a name.

questions.question: What is a Docker image layer?
questions.correctAnswer: A layer is a read-only file representing a part of the Docker image's filesystem.
questions.wrongAnswer1: A layer is a running instance of a Docker container.
questions.wrongAnswer2: A layer is a network configuration of a Docker container.
questions.wrongAnswer3: A layer is the Dockerfile used to build an image.
questions.explanation: Docker image layers are read-only files that represent intermediate file changes in a Docker image's filesystem. They are stacked to form the final image.

questions.question: How do Docker image layers benefit the image building process?
questions.correctAnswer: They enable caching and reuse of unchanged layers to speed up builds.
questions.wrongAnswer1: They prevent images from being shared between hosts.
questions.wrongAnswer2: They increase the overall size of a Docker image drastically.
questions.wrongAnswer3: They automatically delete unused images from the system.
questions.explanation: By caching image layers, Docker can reuse layers that have not changed, making image builds faster and more efficient.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Docker image layers is true?
questions.correctAnswer: Each layer in a Docker image is stacked on top of previous layers to form a single unified filesystem.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Each layer acts as an independent and isolated container environment.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Layers are mutable and can be changed after the image is created.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Docker image layers do not share any filesystem data with each other.
questions.explanation: Docker image layers are stacked read-only filesystems that combine to form the image's filesystem, enabling efficient storage and sharing of layers.
